content.name: title_3
content.content:
Young Onset Dementia

Information for patients, carers and professionals

content.name: html_1
content.content:
Introduction to YOD App

This app is developed for Young Onset Dementia Patients and Carers

Young Onset Dementia (YOD) defined as the onset of dementia before the age of 65 years is increasingly recognised as an important clinical and social problem with devastating consequences for the patients and those who care for them. Accessing age appropriate information and services for young people with the early onset of dementia is limited and this has been concluded through our experience of working with this particular area of dementia.

Following a successful bid to East Midlands Strategic Clinical Network Innovation Funds, we developed an app for YOD patients and carers. It was led by Dr Velayudhan and developed as collaboration between Mental Health Service for Older People, Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust and NHS Leicestershire Health Informatics Service.

"I believe it (this app) will help others at the time they leave the diagnosis appointment so that they can read it over the next few days as you need to have time to work it all out."

It is intended that the app is presented to patient and carers at the time of diagnosis so that in their own time, patient and family members can use guidance to help them to manage all aspects of their life and more importantly signpost them to an array of services and organisations that provide specialised support and information, locally, regionally and nationally. Signposting information is categorised, such as; finances, transport, employment, living well, relationships etc. with contact details for these resources and links to websites such as Alzheimer's Society and YoungDementia UK.

"It is good to have it available to be able to revisit as and when you need to look for certain information."

The YOD app is aimed at patients, families, and health professionals alike. The app aims to empower patients and carers with appropriate information, knowledge and support following diagnosis.

Note: Quotes are from members of a focus group of young onset dementia patients with their families and/or carers who reviewed the app prior to publication.

Project Team: Dr Latha Velayudhan (Consultant Psychiatrist), Sam Stuart (Healthcare Support Worker), Rebecca Cooper (Occupational Therapist), Dr Samantha Hamer (Consultant Psychiatrist), Clare Kozlowski (Community Manager), Gemma Clayton (Business and Marketing Manager, LHIS), Gurtej Brar (Technical Services Manager, LHIS), Sarah Ost (Service Delivery Manager, LHIS), Ibrahim Pardiwala (Technical Support Specialist, LHIS)

Young Onset Dementia
What is it? Find out more
Young Onset Dementia Assessment
At Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust
Living with Young Onset Dementia
Considering and managing aspects of everyday life
Service Directory
Local and national support services

content.name: title_6
content.content: Help

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Tips for using this app


Following links

To access links you will need an internet/mobile data connection from your device. Please be aware that this will use your data allowance if you are connected to 3G/4G internet, so we recommend using the app whilst connected to free WiFi.

Once a link has been accessed it will open in a new window in your default browser.

Phone numbers

If are accessing this app from a mobile phone, touching a phone link will open your phone function with the number to dial.

Email links

Touching an email link will open an email account or choice of email accounts if they are set up on your device. If you do not have any email account(s) set up, then you will probably see a page displaying a list of email providers so you can set one up if you wish.

Maps in the Service Directory

Some Service Directory listings contain a postcode and a map view. Touch the Google logo in the lower left hand side of the map to open in Google maps, either on the browser or in its own app (if it is already installed on your device).

Viewing videos

Videos are in mp4 format and should be playable on most devices. They can be viewed full screen using the expand icon (usually on the far right hand side) on the the play bar at the bottom of the video.

content.name: item_7933222f
content.content: Young Onset Dementia (YOD) Assessment

content.name: html_1
content.content:
Latha Velayudhan, Introduction by Consultant Psychiatrist

Steve Perry, Community Psychiatric Nurse

Becky Cooper, Occupational Therapist

Samantha Stuart, Healthcare Support Worker

Patient

Readable Information

LPT Supporting Services

Assessment Information

Young onset dementia assessment is offered as part of Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trusts Mental Health Services for Older People (MHSOP). Assessments are normally carried out in a clinic or at home for people under 65 years with cognitive impairment and/or memory problems, suspected to be due to a progressive neurodegenerative disorder.

The service provides a clinic-based diagnostic assessment for people under 65 who have cognitive problems which are suspected to be due to a dementia.

Following assessment and diagnosis, the care of the patients will be transferred to the locality MHSOP memory services or CMHT for cholinesterase inhibitors or other drug therapies and further clinical inputs, if they have progressive dementia.

Those with mild cognitive impairment and nonprogressive conditions will be discharged back to their GP. People with any underlying medical or psychiatric disorders other than dementia will be referred back to respective services for further treatment.

Patient Access Points

The Neville Centre
Leicester General Hospital Site
Gwendolen Road
Leicester
LE5 4QG

The Neville Centre, has been open since December 2013 and provides modern facilities on the Leicester General Hospital site. Patient car parking is available in front of the Neville Centre.

Contact Us:

Phone 0116 295 1350

Get directions for the Neville Centre

Referrals can be received from

  • General Practicioners (GPs)
  • Healthcare professionals (Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust and University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust)

content.name: title_6
content.content: Young Onset Dementia

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Dementia is considered 'young onset' when it affects people under 65 years of age. This can also be referred to as 'early onset or working age' dementia.

Although the symptoms of dementia can be similar regardless of age, younger people may have different needs and therefore need different support.

It can be difficult to diagnose dementia in younger people and they can be understandably reluctant to accept there is something wrong when they are otherwise fit and well.

This app aims to provide information and resources for:

  • Anyone concerned that they or a relative or friend may have young onset dementia.
  • Anyone currently living with young onset dementia.
  • Carers, friends or relatives of someone living with young onset dementia.
  • Healthcare professionals who wish to understand the support available in Leicestershire for young onset dementia.

It is important for those living with dementia to understand that they are not alone. As of May 2015 there were over 850,000 in the UK living with dementia of which over 40,000 are under the age of 65 and which would be considered young onset dementia.

For young onset dementia this percentage could be lower owing to the difficulty of diagnosis, lack of awareness and tendency to attribute symptoms to stress or depression in working age people. Obtaining a diagnosis is an important step in gaining access to treatment and support for the person living with dementia. It also can lead to support for carers and gives friends and family valuable time to adjust.

Types of dementia in younger people

Dementia is a category that covers a large number (over 400 in total) of brain diseases which cause a long term and often gradual reduction in the ability of a person to think and remember. The most common forms of dementia in younger people are:

  • Alzheimers disease
  • Vascular dementia
  • Fronto-temporal dementia
  • Dementia with lewybodies
  • Alcohol related brain impairment

Further information about young onset dementia can be found on the Alzheimer's Society and YoungDementia UK websites.

Signs and Symptoms

Symptoms will vary depending on the individual and the type of dementia. The onset of symptoms may be gradual affecting confidence and behaviour. Some of the possible symptoms include:

  • Depression
  • Changes in personality and mood
  • Periods of mental confusion
  • Difficulty finding the right words
  • Problems controlling emotions
  • Loss of empathy - understanding and compassion
  • Planning and organising becomes difficult
  • Social situations become challenging
  • Increasing difficulties with tasks and activities that require concentration and planning
  • Hallucinations
  • Making false claims or statement

content.name: title_6
content.content: Living with Young Onset Dementia

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Being diagnosed with dementia does not mean stopping things you enjoy, however it may be that you have to do them in a different way. The sections below provide tips and resources to support you to live as well as possible. In addition to this information the Alzheimers Society has a range of helpful factsheets

Living Well
Emotional Impact
Relationships
Health and Wellbeing
Working
Driving and Travel
Finances
Activities

content.name: title_6
content.content: About

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust

Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust (LPT) provides mental health, learning disability and community health services for a population of more than a million people, mainly living in Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland. The Trust employs approximately 5,500 staff. Find out more about our people and our work at www.leicspart.nhs.uk/

Follow us on Twitter @LPTnhs

Leicestershire Health Informatics Service (LHIS)

The NHS Leicestershire Health Informatics Service (LHIS) is a mature Information Management & Technology (IM&T) provider employing over 130 members of staff, supporting customer organisations across the UK with IT services and tailored IT solutions. Find out more about what LHIS can do for you at www.leics-his.nhs.uk.


Follow us on Twitter @LeicsHis



Commontime

CommonTime are a leading provider of mobile technology for the healthcare sector. Find out more about what Commontime can do for you at www.commontime.com.

Follow us on Twitter @CT_Healthcare

content.name: title_6
content.content: Living Well

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Supporting those living with dementia are approximately over 700,000 informal carers and a wide range of agencies, charities and organisations that are there to provide support, care and guidance. The Department of Health estimate that 59 percent of people with dementia in England have a formal diagnosis.

The information in this section of the app combined with the service directory aims to provide tips and information to support getting the most out of life and help with adapting to changes as they occur

Follow this link to the NHS Choices video where an expert explains the value of early diagnosis and planning for the future, and John and his wife Shirley describe how they have adapted their lives since John showed early signs of dementia.

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Emotional Impact

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Being told that you or someone close to you has been diagnosed with young onset dementia is a major thing and will impact emotionally with potentially confusing emotions. This is a normal and understandable response to the changes you are dealing with.

Things that may help you include:

  • Talking to a friend or family member
  • Ask for help from one of the many support services available (see our service directory for these)
  • Trying to ensure you still do the things you enjoy in life to support you and your wellbeing
  • Accepting there is no right or wrong way to feel and that it will take time to work through the emotions you are experiencing

Beyond the initial diagnosis, living with dementia can lead to experiencing changes and swings in mood with feelings of sadness, anger, fear or frustration as the disease progresses.

For family and friends it can be difficult to stay positive. It is important to remember you are not alone and that help and support is available. Sharing your worries or concerns can help be it with a family member, friend, GP or support group.

YoungDementia UK has advice on explaining to family and friends and also on telling children about a young onset dementia diagnosis. There is also advice on who else to tell.

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Relationships

content.name: html_2
content.content:
For those living with or caring for someone with dementia it is important to keep an active social life maintaining contact with others. For those living with dementia this will help keep them active and stimulated.

It can be difficult for people to talk about their own or a family members dementia or people may want to help but dont know how to. In this case it is important where possible to not lose touch. Often this may mean having to make the first move explaining that you need to see them and how they can help.

Many support groups exist and although many people can be put off by the idea of joining a group the opportunity to be part of a community of people with dementia or a group of families who have a member with dementia can be helpful. Often this can provide sharing of experiences, insights, useful information and tips from others who are going through or have been through similar situations.

The Alzheimers Society has relationship information and advice here.

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: title_6
content.content: Health and Wellbeing

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Health

Living healthily is important for everyone, including those with dementia. Poor health through diet and/or lifestyle has been proven to increase the risk of developing dementia.

Having a healthy lifestyle, eating well and exercising will contribute to overall quality of life and support emotional wellbeing. Changes in eating habits can occur and it is important to maintain regular meals to avoid weight loss and poor nutrition.

The Live Well section of NHS Choices has health and wellbeing information and advice for everyone.

NHS Choices Live Well links

Here are some links to the Live Well section of the NHS Choices website that you may find helpful and inspiring:

  • All Topics
  • Exercise
  • Food and diet
  • Sleep
  • Living with a condition
  • Stop smoking

Tap below to access more details of organisations and services that specialise in health and well-being.


Healthcare links and organisations

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Working

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Many people are still able to work after being diagnosed with young onset dementia. Continuing to work can support self-esteem, keep the brain active, provide income and support maintaining an active social life. Where there is stress and anxiety with struggling to continue working Occupational Therapy (OT) can become involved to support maintaining employment.

Timing about informing an employer is down to the individual to decide though it is important to check if there is a requirement to inform the employer about changes that could impact on safety at work or if driving forms part of the job. Disclosure to an employer should lead to gaining legal rights and support.

The Alzheimers Society has an employment booklet with further information.

Your rights

Dementia is a disability as defined in the Equality Act 2010. This is due to it being a long term condition that lasts more than 12 months and has an effect on normal day to day activity.

The Act requires employers to avoid discrimination and make reasonable adjustments to ensure people with dementia are not disadvantaged in the workplace. Reasonable adjustments might include changes to working hours, part time working, aids or equipment to support doing a job.

  • The government has more general information here: GOV.UK
  • The Dementia Engagement and Empowerment Project (DEEP) has published a guide for employers who would like to be more dementia friendly, to download it follow this link: GOV.UK - DEEP Guide - Tips for employers
  • Employers are also obliged to consider requests for flexible working from carers under the Flexible Working Regulations (2006): YoungDementia UK Information on Working & Volunteering

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Driving and Travel

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Can I still drive?

The DVLA (Driving Vehicle Licencing Authority) can provide an assessment to determine if someone diagnosed with young onset dementia can continue driving. The DVLA has a form which is used to provide information and if this turns out to be difficult to fill out then a friend or family member may be able to help.

Following this an assessment may be requested and if the DVLA decides that it is safe to continue driving then a new license will be issued for a limited period with a regular follow up review required. If it is decided by the DVLA that driving has to stop then it is possible to appeal the decision and the DVLA website has information on this.

Does it matter when I do it?

It is important to notify the DVLA and your insurer immediately after a diagnosis of dementia as it can potentially invalidate insurance and lead to a fine of up to 1,000.

Insurance

It is illegal to drive without valid insurance in the UK and someone close may be able to talk to the insurers on your behalf if you are not able to do so personally.

Tips and ideas

If you can carry on driving it might help to only drive on routes that are well known to you or on quieter roads with less traffic. It may also help to have a passenger accompany you for your journey.

As with any driving it is important to not drive when tired as this can be dangerous and make the experience more stressful. It is wise to pullover if starting to feel unwell or confused.

Alternatives

It can feel as though independence has been lost for those no longer able to drive or when the time comes that it is no longer possible. However there are alternatives available to restore the sense of freedom and independence and enable travel. Taxis, lifts from friends/ family and public transport can enable travel without driving.

Bus Passes

It may well be that you are entitled to a free bus pass.

  • Throughout England and wales a free bus pass is available to eligible disabled people and those over 60 in England and Wales.
  • Disabled people and people over 60 are entitled to free bus travel anywhere in Scotland with a National Entitlement Card.

Train travel

  • Discount railcards are available which can reduce fares by up to a third for yourself and a companion.
  • Many companies offer travel assistance to help with boarding a train and to provide advice at the end of the journey.

Taxi

  • Setting up an account with a local taxi company can be useful as it saves worrying about having money to hand.
  • If a taxi driver is particularly understanding and helpful it may be useful to request that driver each time, particularly when travelling alone.
  • Some local councils have a taxi scheme offering free or reduced taxi travel for people with dementia.

Useful Links

  • www.disabledpersons-railcard.co.uk
  • www.gov.uk/dementia-and-driving

Transport and travel links and organisations

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Finances

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Young onset dementia may well affect income and financial commitments. This might include giving up work earlier than planned which could have a considerable impact if there are dependants or significant financial commitments.

Even if you are on top of your finances and managing them well it is always good to plan ahead and it is often cheaper to have procedures in place early on for managing your finances.

Tap the button below this list to investigate these considerations:

  • Bank Accounts
  • Lasting power of attorney - GOV.UK information
  • Making a Will
  • Pensions and retirement
  • Benefits
  • Grants
  • Paying for care and support

Finance and benefit links and organisations

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e
content.content:
• Home
  • Help
  • About
  • Terms
  • Contact

content.name: title_6
content.content: Activities

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Being diagnosed with young onset dementia should not mean an end to the things that you enjoy and stop you living a full life. To achieve this and live well with dementia will mean adapting to the changes as they occur.

Some things that may be of help can include:

  • Building up a support network of family, friends, groups and organisations who can provide reassurance and support
  • Socialising, exercise and eating a healthy diet
  • Equipment, electronic reminders and adaptions can help to make the home safer and support independence
  • Technologies such as Skype and FaceTime can support communications and keeping in touch

It is important to continue to enjoy hobbies and interests bearing in mind that activities may need to change over time as the illness progresses. It is important to remember that those living with dementia can and should enjoy their spare time.

  • Leicester Ageing Together for upcoming events that may interest you
Activities and leisure links and organisations

content.name: html_9
content.content: Top

content.name: item_ea345a2e

content.name: title_6
content.content: LPT Supporting Services

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust Supporting Services

Health Services for Older People (MHSOP)
Open Mind Service
The Memory Service
Occupational Therapy for Adults
Speech and Language Therapy
Nutrition and Dietetics
Leicestershire Recovery College

Supporting Services

Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust offers a wide array of services. The services listed below are ones which more commonly might be accessed by someone living with dementia.

How Can You Access Our Services?

To access our service you can:

  • Speak to your GP
  • Speak to any other healthcare professional involved in your care

Mental Health Services for Older People (MHSOP)

What Does Our Service Do?

Mental Health Services for Older People provide specialist diagnosis and care to people of all ages with probable dementia and people over 65 years of age with depression, anxiety and psychotic illnesses. A range of services offer different levels of support dependent on the severity of your illness at that time.

The majority of people we see will also have some physical health needs or other age-related issues.

Access to Mental Health Services for Older People

The Community Mental Health Teams are the first point of access for people who use Mental Health Services for Older People. Referrals are received via GPs. All Mental Health Services for Older People are initially accessed via the locality based Community Mental Health Teams.

Once a referral has been received the patient will be contacted by the most appropriate team who can meet your current needs. First contact will begin with an assessment of your needs and this also provides an opportunity for you and your carer to ask any questions as well as talk about thoughts, anxieties and expectations.

Who do our teams include?

Speech and Language Therapists:

They will work with you if you have difficulties communicating. They will complete an assessment and suggest ways to make communication easier for you and the people you communicate with. They also work with you if you have difficulties eating and swallowing your food and drink. They will suggest ways to make this easier and/or safer for you.

Occupational Therapists (OT):

They will look at how you manage every day activities from getting dressed to cooking a meal, particularly concentrating on how your mental and physical health affects these activities. The OT can help to find ways to make these activities easier and/or safer.

Psychologists:

Clinical psychologists act on a consultancy basis to all service areas providing psychology advice to the multidisciplinary team. They also offer a direct therapy service to patients and carry out assessments of memory change and other cognitive disorders.

Consultant psychiatrist and other doctors:

They will assess mental health and arrange for investigations in order to provide a diagnosis. They may prescribe and monitor medications and give general advice and information about your condition.

Registered mental health nurses:

They will assess your mental health and provide advice, support and information about your condition. They will monitor your mental health medication and provide you with support and advice to enable you to manage your illness. The needs of carers will also be considered.

Our services include: Inpatient services

Our wards care for the most vulnerable patients during periods of acute mental illness and when they are too unwell to be cared for in the community.

Coleman, Gwendolen and Wakerley wards are based at the Evington Centre, with Kirby and Welford Wards at the Bennion Centre. They specialise in assessment and care of patients with dementia.

Welcome to MHSOP Inpatient Services patient leaflet


Memory Service

The Memory Service provides diagnostic assessment and treatment for people with dementia within an outpatient clinic setting. Clinics are held across the city and county.

Open Mind Service

The Open Mind service provides confidential, recovery-focused talking therapies for adults who are stressed, depressed or have anxiety.

It is available to people aged 16 and over (including the over 65s) who are registered with a GP in the city of Leicester.

The Open Mind Service offers a range of approved therapies aimed at helping people towards recovery, and covers every GP practice in Leicester City.

We have a range of therapists,including psychological wellbeing practitioners and mental health facilitators who are trained in a range of interventions approved by the National Institute of Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE).

There are three ways to get help from the service:

  • A referral from your GP
  • A referral through any other healthcare professional involved in your care
  • You can refer yourself to our free stress management course

Occupational Therapy for Adults

Occupational therapists work to identify your strengths and limitations and find ways of assisting with these to encourage independence, maintain your skills and improve your quality of life.

Speech and Language Therapy

What Does Our Service Do?

The Speech and Language Therapy Service for adults is provided across Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland. The service aims to provide specialist, effective, efficient and responsive intervention for adults with primarily acquired communication and/or swallowing difficulties.

How Does Our Service Work?

Our speech and language therapists work in hospitals and health centres across Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland. We see people when they are in hospital, as outpatients and in their own homes.

We provide services at:

  • the Leicester Royal Infirmary, Leicester General Hospital and Glenfield Hospital
  • community hospitals
  • some health centres
  • home for some patients

If you are referred for a speech and language therapy assessment the therapist will take a history of your communication and/or swallowing difficulties and may carry out some assessments to understand the difficulties more fully. You will work together to develop a plan to help with your needs. You may only need a single appointment or may need a course of therapy, but you will discuss this with your speech and language therapist.

Nutrition and Dietetics

What Does Our Service Do?

The Nutrition and Dietetic service provides advice for adults and children regarding their nutrition, and also provides training and education for other health professionals to enable them to promote good nutrition. Good nutrition is vital for health and wellbeing, and Dietitians advise on both general healthy eating for people of different ages, and also nutrition in specific situations examples include malnutrition and nutritional deficiencies, overweight, diabetes, cancer, coeliac disease, heart disease, and allergies or food intolerances. Dietitians work in close liaison with other health professionals; including doctors, nurses, pharmacists and speech and language therapists. We also work with other agencies such as education and social services.

For people wishing to attend weight management groups, details of these are also available from our headquarters.

Leicestershire Recovery College

We have developed a Recovery College. The college provides a range of recovery focused courses, seminars and workshops for people accessing adult mental health services and for their relatives, friends and loved ones - and for our own Trust staff.

The courses are free and aim to support people to recognise and develop their personal resourcefulness, resilience and talents in order to become experts in their own self care, make informed choices and help them achieve their aspirations and goals in life.

There are no entry requirements to enrol. We have an online enrolment form or you can can complete a paper form, to post to the college, alternatively you can enrol by phone on 0116 295 1196. The college is based on the Glenfield Hospital site for more information. The college is normally open 9.30am-3.00pm (although some courses may run past this time).

content.name: title_6
content.content: Assessment Information

content.name: html_2
content.content:
Video transcripts

The following sections expand to give an overview of roles and responsibilities of those involved with a patient from diagnosis and also a patient's account of how he tries to live his life as positively as possible.

Introduction by the Consultant Psychiatrist

Hello! My name is Latha Velayudhan and I am a consultant Old Age Psychiatrist. The Memory Services within Mental Health Services for Older People (MHSOP) at Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust offers assessment and care for people under 65 years of age with memory problems suspected to be due to dementia.

Who can refer?

Referrals are mostly made by General Practitioners (GPs) but also other specialists such as neurologists.

What do the LPT Memory Services do?

We carry out comprehensive assessment which includes detailed history taking, memory testing and investigations such as brain scans. Other professionals such as Psychologists, Speech and Language Therapists, Occupational Therapists (OTs) also provide assessments and inputs.

What happens after diagnosis?

If someone is diagnosed with dementia, depending on the type of dementia they will be commenced on medications such as cholinesterase inhibitors, for which they are monitored and supported within the memory services or by their own GPs. Some people may require further inputs and they will be referred to Community Mental Health Team for inputs from professionals such as Community Psychiatry Nurses (CPNs), Occupational Therapists(OTs) and Healthcare Support Workers (HCSWs).

Community Psychiatric Nurse

Hello! My name is Steve Perry and I am a Community Psychiatric Nurse (CPN).

When a person is referred with a memory problem, my role is to monitor the effects of the medication, to note any side effects and generally how the person is feeling on the medication and if they are having a good response.

Some CPNs are registered prescribers, so may instigate medication and titrate the dosage (this means to move the dosage up in relation to how the person reacts).

Another important part of my role is to liaise with the other multi-disciplinary team members and that is when we bring all of our assessments together which gives a comprehensive profile of the individual who has been referred and this gives us the best idea of what the next step should be.

An important part of my job is to liaise with all others involved, this could be; other clinicians, social services or the voluntary sector.

Occupational Therapist

Hello! My name is Becky Cooper and I am an Occupational Therapist (OT). A person with a diagnosis of early or young onset dementia will often experience difficulties in carrying out everyday activities and this is when an Occupational Therapist will become involved in a person's care.

A detailed assessment looking at all aspects of a person's life will help to identify problems that a person is experiencing. The OT will take an holistic approach and will not only look at the person, but their environment, their family, social life, work life and their hobbies. The problems identified are different for everyone and the OT will work with you to find out what is important for you in your life.

The role of the OT can be very varied; we can be asked to provide aides and adaptations for someone with poor mobility, we can help carers adapt the ways in which they communicate with their loved ones to help make their lives easier, or we can help a person build their confidence when using public transport as they may have had to give up driving. It might be that someone has had to give up work leaving very little structure and routine to their day and the OT can look at social outlets and help identify hobbies and interests that a person wants to pursue and this can help them to increase their feelings of wellbeing.

Often people become hugely frustrated about forgetting things and annoyed about having to ask somebody all of the time. The OT can look at visual prompts around the home as well as a variety of assistive technology that can act as an aide for your memory throughout the day and can help just give you back that bit of control and independence that you have lost.

Working with people with early onset dementia, we (OTs) will often work closely alongside the family to help them on this journey. There may be families with children who are having difficulties coming to terms with their parent's diagnosis and just not understanding the symptoms they are seeing or there may be children who are providing care for their parent and may be struggling. An OT can help to identify what help is needed and get in touch with various charities and agencies who can provide that support and care that they may need with these issues.

These are just some the examples of how an OT can help. It is important to remember that each person will have a different experience and that the OT will look at each person's need individually.

Healthcare Support Worker

Hello! My name is Samantha Stuart and I am a Healthcare Support Worker (HCSW) working with people with a young onset dementia.

Healthcare Support Workers within the Leicestershire Partnership NHS Trust Community Mental Health Team (CMHT) work closely with Community Psychiatric Nurses (CPNs) and Occupational Therapists (OTs).

My role is varied in the way it supports people and families living with young onset dementia (YOD) and I provide support by meeting the needs identified within their care plan.

When a person is first diagnosed I am able to provide a listening ear, reassurance and support as they start their journey of living with a young onset dementia.

I spend time building a therapeutic relationship with a person with dementia to enable them to explore ways to learn to cope and live well with their diagnosis. Carer support!

I initially visit people at home and work with Occupational Therapists to help build up confidence with their daily activities at work and within the local area to remain socially active.

I signpost and liaise with other supportive services including local councils, social services, voluntary agencies and work closely with them to ensure that the appropriate services are offered.

I then work with the person living with dementia and offer practical support to find purposeful activities so that the person remains socially active and integrated within their community by supporting them to attend various social activities which are meaningful to them. This might be by enabling them to access the various opportunities that are happening in their local area.

Patient

With special thanks to Alex for sharing his experience after diagnosis of young onset dementia.

My life was very different, it was total general chaos, so many things changed. So I decided I will play music, so that's what I do and move along. I play guitar and enjoy my life as much as I can, enjoy the family, children and grandchildren.

After initial diagnosis I went into a downer. I was wondering what's going to happen in life and you think about your family. It's not just robbing you from the family, and its robbing them from me. But I decided I can't just sit around and I got back into music and started playing guitar more.

For years I had a good job, but I hadn't written music and never ever thought of recording. Now suddenly thought, well I might try and record some songs. I've now teamed up with some people and a very well-known record producer who are very interested in what I am doing and I thought I will do this while I still can.

And there is problem for me you see. Whilst I can still write music and play guitar, but I struggle now in front of people. But I have got very good musicians who help me, and I am now more positive. I go along to studios, I know what I want and I can play what I want and I work with people and it takes my mind off from what's happening. They are all used to me "dropping out of the room" when they say things to me and coming back after a couple of minutes. It can be a bit frustrating. But people understand and get to know you. I don't mind people taking the mick. I quite enjoy a bit of banter because it lightens the mood. I am not one of those who feel offended but people can be rude about things. For example, lot of people look at me and because I can talk they say I am not like their granddad or grandmaÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ¦ And I say no, I am not like your grandma or granddad as they may have developed the illness later on their life. I am not at that stage but that doesn't mean it's not there. Because you can't see it doesn't mean it's gone away. If I broke my arm, people will see and say "oh, you have broken your arm". But this illness is not like that. But I will keep going.

Alex's advice to others

The other thing I will say to people is don't hide away. Do not hide away from it. It is difficult. I go to banks, and sometimes because I am affected with numbers, I say to people in the bank you got to help me with this. They look at me strange for a start and I will tell them what's wrong with me and then they normally quite good and people will help. I never had people in bank and other places look at me strangely but in life people will look at you strangely. They sometimes say you can talk so what is the matter with you. But they don't understand all the other things that are going on. But don't put yourself in a box.
